Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60G8-6W91-DXH2-6305-00000-00Big Tech Questioned In Congress; Oregon State Police To Enter Portland, Federal Agents Staying Until Violence Ends; Donald Trump Jr. On Twitter's Decision To Temporarily Suspend Account; Putting An End To Leftwing Violence; Big Tech's Anti-Conservative Bias; U.S. To Withdraw Nearly 12,000 Troops From Germany, Ecuador On Alert Over Huge Chinese Fishing Fleet Off Galapagos Islands; Freight Train Catches Fire And Derails In Arizona2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:23:04ZLexisNexisLOU DOBBS TONIGHT7:00 PM ESTDonald Trump Jr., Sidney Powell, Sebastian Gorka, Robert WoodsonNEWSFinancial072901cb.229Big Tech Questioned In Congress; Oregon State Police To Enter Portland, Federal Agents Staying Until Violence Ends; Donald Trump Jr. On Twitter's Decision To Temporarily Suspend Account; Putting An End To Leftwing Violence; Big Tech's Anti-Conservative Bias; U.S. To Withdraw Nearly 12,000 Troops From Germany, Ecuador On Alert Over Huge Chinese Fishing Fleet Off Galapagos Islands; Freight Train Catches Fire And Derails In ArizonaLou Dobbs

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Good evening, everybody. The CEOs of tech giants Amazon, Facebook, Apple and Google today, testifying before a House Judiciary subcommittee.

Lawmakers questioning four of the world's richest men in their virtual hearing about their massive companies that dominate technology and social media.

The tech Titans are worth about $200 billion looking every bit the part of avaricious and voracious Masters of the Universe, looking to destroy anything in their path. Just kidding.

All four CEOs looked impossibly passive as they demurred to the awesome power of the U.S. Congress. They were dismissive of any notion that they, of all people, would stifle competition or could in any way strangle free speech and crush conservative voices and votes.

They claim to be the farthest thing from monopolist or oligarchs. They compete not only against one another and viciously, but also others.

Google CEO, Sundar Pichai claims his company is facing intense competition, yet somehow, some way Google manages to dominate search traffic accounting for -- are you ready -- almost 92 percent of all searches done online -- 92 percent. That's very close to monopolistic, don't you think?

And Google also remains the largest digital ad platform by market share. Last year, nearly 32 percent of all digital advertising dollars were spent on Google. The company paying a $1.7 billion fine in March to the European Union, where they stood accused of abusing the giant advertising market. Dominance -- that denial was found to be absurd.

All four companies today though, under investigation by the Justice Department and a number of State Attorneys General for monopolistic anti- competitive behavior, and they're looking into whether these big tech companies should be -- pardon the expression -- broken up.

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg was asked directly about that, grilled on whether his company bought the now popular app Instagram in order to neutralize a potential competitor. Perish the thought. Here's his response.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK ZUCKERBERG, CEO, FACEBOOK: I've always been clear that we've used Instagram both as a competitor and as a compliment to our services.

I think with hindsight, it probably looks like obvious that Instagram would have reached the scale that it has today. But at the time, it was far from obvious.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos seemed to -- well, to garner the least attention and had the fewest questions of the day, but he did reveal Amazon may be using some access to critical third-party data in order to build their own competitive products, and to further -- well, increase their revenue.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. RASHIDA TLAIB (D-MI): Mr. Bezos, does Amazon ever access and use third-party seller data when making business decisions and just a yes or no will suffice, sir.

JEFF BEZOS, CEO, AMAZON: I can't answer that question yes or no. What I can tell you is we have a policy against using seller specific data to aid our private label business. But I can't guarantee you that that policy has never been violated.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Well, darn the luck. On the censorship of conservatives, Congressman Jim Jordan, the strongest voice in that room as he blasted the obvious political bias of Silicon Valley and Big Tech.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. JIM JORDAN (R-OH): Big Tech is out the get conservatives. That's not a suspicion. That's not a hunch. That's a fact. July 20, 2020, Google removes the homepages of Breitbart and "The Daily Caller."

Just last night, we learned Google has censored Breitbart. So much traffic has declined 99 percent. June 16, 2020, Google threatens to de-monetize and ban "The Federalist." April 19, 2020, Google and YouTube announced a policy censoring the content that conflicts with recommendations of the World Health Organization.

Now, think about that. The World Health Organization, the organization that lied to us, the organization that shielded for China, and if you contradict something they say, they can say whatever they want. They can lie for China. They conceal for China. You say something against them, you get censored.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: No obvious solutions were proffered. Congressman Jordan also targeted Google's CEO demanding his assurance that Google would not tip the scales for the Dems in November.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JORDAN: This is a simple question. Can you today assure Americans you will not tailor your features in any way to help specifically help one candidate over other in this -- what I'm concerned about is you helping Joe Biden over President Trump?

SUNDAR PICHAI, CEO, GOOGLE: We won't do any work, you know, to politically tilt anything one way or the other. It's against our core values.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: There, I hope you feel better. Oregon's radical Dem Governor, Kate Brown today finally -- finally choosing to pay attention to her oath of office and stump up to end the mob violence in Portland, Oregon that has ravaged Portland for more than two months now.

Oregon State Police will now be deployed to Downtown Portland under the plan agreed with D.H.S. The Federal officers who are now guarding Federal property won't leave, however, until those troopers and local law enforcement are in place, and the unrest and violence has ended.

The Federal agents last night once again were forced to deploy teargas. The anarchists and activists of Antifa and Black Lives Matter firing fireworks at the officers and agents projectiles. President Trump this morning, unloaded on Oregon's Democratic officials.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: They are anarchists. They are radical crazy people, and they are either going straighten out by themselves, Portland and the police, and maybe have the state heads involved. That is the Governor and the Mayor, but they are very weak people.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: The Justice Department today also announced expansion of its Operation Legend that program designed to help local police in their fight against rising violence. The program now expanding to Cleveland, Detroit and Milwaukee. The initiative is already in place in Kansas City, Chicago and Albuquerque.

Research psychologist Dr. Robert Epstein says Google wants to shift 10 percent of the voting public away from President Trump to make populism a quote, "blip in history." But that isn't what the CEO of Google said, is it? Dr. Epstein says, telling Breitbart, quote, "One of the things that was said there by one of their top executives is, quote, 'we're going to use every means at our disposal, all of Google's power to make sure Trump isn't reelected.'"

"So if they're using every single means at their disposal, then they're using all of the techniques that I've discovered and probably more that I haven't discussed yet, and that's enough to shift roughly 10 percent of the voting population of the United States with no one knowing they're being manipulated. No paper trail for authorities to trace."

Well joining us tonight who knows something about the power of Big Tech and Silicon Valley, we're joined by Donald Trump Jr., Executive Vice President of the Trump Organization, bestselling author and of course, son of President Donald Trump.

Don, Jr.'s Twitter account was restricted yesterday after twitting a video highlighting the benefits of hydroxychloroquine. Don, it's great to have you with us on the show. Can you hear me?

DONALD TRUMP JR., EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT, TRUMP ORGANIZATION (via phone): Yes.

DOBBS: First, I've got to -- good. I want to ask you, first of all, your reaction to being suspended by Twitter for effectively promoting that video extolling the benefits of hydroxychloroquine.

TRUMP JR.: Well, I didn't even say anything about it. What was interesting about it, Lou, I think we're having a little technical difficulties because I'm in the van. I'm actually doing this now in the vehicle because the satellite feed isn't working.

But I simply said, this is an interesting counterpoint to what you're hearing and the narrative that you're getting every day from Democrats. And, you know, and/or the mainstream media.

It was a group of doctors, about a dozen of them and they were talking about, hey, we've treated real patients with it. We've seen this, why is that there? So I said, this is interesting. People should listen to this. People should hear and hear a dissenting opinion.

I didn't say it was right or wrong, and for that, I got thrown off of Twitter for 12 hours. It happened to numerous other people as well, and it's amazing that the doctors at Twitter apparently know more than actual life medical professional, dozens of them that were standing on the steps of Congress with some congressmen.

DOBBS: Mark Zuckerberg today obviously making it very clear to the assembled congressmen that he didn't have anything to do with your suspension or Sidney Powell, General Flynn's defense attorney, her account, but saying at the same time that he didn't want to be an arbiter of truth that his company was doing precisely that, that Twitter, he acknowledged was doing exactly that deciding what is valid, what is invalid, what is true and that isn't their role nor is it their prerogative under our Constitution to do so.

What are -- what are we going to do? We are watching this hearing today, but I don't know it's going to solve much.

TRUMP JR.: I don't know that it's going to solve much because Republicans have to wake up to this problem and then obviously, Mark Zuckeberg is Facebook, the issue I had was with Twitter.

But you know, they all do the same thing. I see it, Instagram which is owned by Facebook did the same thing to me last year when I called out the Jussie Smollett hoax before everyone because I just said, hey, this is ridiculous and I got thrown off Instagram for a while with my post taken down for apparently perpetuating hate speech.

I didn't say anything. I actually said, has anyone even bothered to look into this story because it seems really, really, really ridiculously farfetched.

It turns out, I was right, but that didn't stop them from labeling me as someone who provoked hate speech, that didn't stop then the media from taking that and running with it that I'm promoting conspiracy theories.

You know, it's not -- it's only a conspiracy theory until you're proven right, which I obviously was. That said, it didn't change anything.

So the problem we have in Congress is that many Republicans, they don't know anything about social media. They're not on it. Some young staffer is doing it. They don't see these things.

And more importantly, they're not in touch with their base, who is just deplatformed, who is censored. Anyone who is religious, anyone who is a Second Amendment supporter, anyone who is pro-life, all of those things are just destroyed and decimated in the algorithms of social media.

And frankly, even in the search engines like Google, look at what Google did to Breitbart. It doesn't end and Republicans are not aware of it. They keep saying it is nonsense, that it's a free market principle. It's not a free market when you're getting government protection.

These companies get billions of dollars' worth of free liability protections from the government. They cannot then function as publishers deciding what you and the American people get to see and what they don't, pushing their liberal, California bordering on communist agenda to the American people because they're attempting to sway in the election.

They're attempting to sway in the way that people think, and it's very effective when people -- ordinary people who don't see what's going on are bombarded with a one-sided, incredibly biased, leftwing, talking point memo on a daily basis on these platforms.

DOBBS: It's truly stunning, the awesome power that these giant tech companies, social media companies with them are exerting on American society right now. It is -- it's stunning.

It is also un-American for this to continue under our antitrust laws, and yet, as you say the Republicans act like scared children when you mention regulating what is obviously monopolistic and anti-competitive behavior.

It is absolutely a juvenile response on the part of Republicans who should know something about economics and politics. Let's talk about politics real quickly. It looks to me like a number of the polls are turning in your father's direction. The President is looking, I think, significantly stronger, despite the polling biases of most of these organizations, your thoughts?

TRUMP JR.: Listen, I think you're right. Again, there's a lot for us to overcome when you talk about that bias. You know, Lou, you and I do this stuff every day. We're watching it 2/7, but for the average person who is, you know, working hard to put food on their table, you know, they're consuming five minutes of news a day and it's 96 percent negative against Donald Trump.

There are people, you know, quote-unquote "professional journalists," who are still perpetrating the Russia hoax nonsense and everything. I mean, it's very hard to overcome that. People have to understand what's going on. People have to understand Joe Biden's path because of quarantine.

I had a few months off. I wrote another book called "Liberal Privilege." It's available on donjr.com, you know, you know, D-O-N-J-R dot com because I basically had four months to look into the background of this 50-year career swamp creature, and he is not the guy that the mainstream media is pushing. He is not the moderate that you think he is.

He is not this reasonable guy, and honestly, if you want Joe Biden and you see the way he behaves, you see how he can't remember where he is. He's just a pawn for the radical left and all you have to do is look on his website and see these Biden standards, communist manifesto joint unity plan to realize that this is a radical guy who is not in charge.

The radical left will be in charge of this Biden presidency, if that ever, God forbid happens, and it will be the end of America as we know it, Lou.

DOBBS: Donald Trump Jr., good to have you with us. Come back soon. All the best and we'll get to these technology problems sorted out between you and us. Thanks a lot, Don.

Turning now to Wall Street. Stocks finishing higher today. The Dow 160 points. The S&P gained 40. The NASDAQ up 141. Volume on the big board picking up to four and a half billion shares.

Crude oil $41.26 a barrel.

Listen to my reports three times a day, coast to coast on the Salem Radio Network.

Up next, the Justice Department investigates the unmasking of President Trump's transition team and his campaign team and his administration. His attorney, Sidney Powell joins us with the latest.

We'd also like to promote my new book, which we're going to do right now, "The Trump Century: How Our President Changed the Course of History Forever." Preorders now. Preorder your copy or copies at thetrumpcentury.com, amazon.com, barnesandnoble.com and save the Republic.

We'll be right back.

DOBBS: Breaking News. Ecuador's Navy is on alert this evening. An armada of 260 Chinese fishing ships is encroaching on the protected waters of the marine reserve around the Galapagos Islands. Let's show you a radar image here if we could, please.

This shows the large cluster as you see labeled there in the lower left on your screen, those boats 200 miles from the islands, but the protected area extends 188 from those islands. So they've encroached within 20 miles of the marine reserve.

Ecuador's former Environment Minister, addressing the Chinese encroachment calling it, "This fleet size and aggressiveness against marine species is a big threat to the balance of species in the Galapagos."

And the White House National Security Council today, supporting Ecuador tweeting its support saying, "The United States stands with President Lenin and our friends and partners in Ecuador against any aggression directed toward their economic and environmental sovereignty." And that is precisely what this is, it is an aggression.

The Attorney General William Barr yesterday reiterated the F.B.I.'s interview of General Flynn was nothing less than an effort to entrap him to, trap him in a lie.

Barr also confirmed that there is an ongoing investigation into the unmasking of General Flynn by high ranking Obama officials. The Attorney General said U.S. Attorney John Bash is looking into the nearly 50 times that Flynn was unmasked in the two months prior to the Trump inauguration.

Joining us now is the attorney for General Michael Flynn, Sidney Powell. She is a former Federal prosecutor, bestselling author and a recent victim of the arbiters of truth at Twitter. You were suspended for, as I understand it, 12 hours, Sidney.

SIDNEY POWELL, ATTORNEY FOR GENERAL MICHAEL FLYNN: I'm still locked out of my account.

DOBBS: Everything is back to normal?

POWELL: Oh, no, I'm still locked out of my account. Yes. I have filed multiple complaints with Twitter --

DOBBS: What's it going to take?

POWELL: I assume it's about hydroxychloroquine.

DOBBS: Well, you know, God forbid anybody expressed an opinion one way or the other on hydroxychloroquine in 21st Century America, the arbiters of truth, led by the -- what would you call him, the Grand Wizard, Jack Dorsey. What is the world are they doing there?

And isn't there -- I mean, when you can be shut out of Twitter, when the son of the President, Donald, Jr. can be run roughshod over like this by social media. We are in a heck of a lot of trouble in this country.

POWELL: We are Lou. I mean, one of our most important foundations of course is freedom of speech. I understand these are private companies, but they benefit substantially from both taxpayer resources and government contracts and the use of the Internet that the taxpayers essentially fund and their ability to censor anything has got to be ended and soon because they are definitely adversely affecting conservative speech and trying to influence this election.

We know that they are owned substantially and have substantial ownerships interest in them by foreign countries. I think Twitter has a substantial ownership interest from someone in Saudi Arabia. They are of course doing business with Communist China.

Google is assisting Communist China with artificial intelligence even for military projects. The entire situation is extremely concerning and the government needs to do something to shut it down now, so that we are allowed basic prestige.

DOBBS: So what can the Federal government do right now? What can the Justice Department do? Because this is anti-competitive behavior. It is the -- it is abuse of what is already monopolistic power.

My god there -- what can the government do?

POWELL: There might even be some criminal statutes that apply, Lou, because of their influence or attempts to influence the election.

It's very clear that it's only conservative speech they are stifling. All of them -- GoogleAmazon, you know, all of them.

DOBBS: But what drives me crazy, Sidney is -- Sid, I mean, this has been going on for years. Go back to the I.R.S. and what they were doing with conservative tax exemptions, applications. I mean this has been going under for eight years of Obama.

It has continued into this administration and there has been no reaction because the Justice Department is so busy prosecuting our President trying to overthrow a presidency that they didn't have time to deal with law and the power of the marketplace.

The Republicans are absolutely comatose.

POWELL: Yes, we have got to have people in government that are willing to assist the President and stop these things from happening. There are ways of doing it, but nobody is acting on them, and so the people are just left to suffer like we're all doing, whether it's from the abject violence or the ridiculous response to COVID by the multiple governors or the social media issues.

DOBBS: Yes, the governors of the Pacific Northwest, the mayors, these Democratic mayors, there should be some sort of legal liability for their ignorance and their efforts to absolutely destroy their cities and leave their citizens exposed to devastation.

Again, the President has said he will use executive action -- orders -- if necessary, because Congress is not going to be able to do anything. They don't want to do anything, the Democrats.

So that's where we're headed, isn't it?

POWELL: Yes, it's a real quandary because there have to be some sort of enforcement mechanisms and then it has to be enforced once the mechanisms are there. We don't seem to have either.

DOBBS: Sidney Powell, thanks for being with us. We appreciate it. Appreciate it.

We'd like to hear your thoughts on all of this, what Sidney Powell gone through, Donald Trump Jr. Follow me on Twitter @LouDobbs. Like me on Facebook. Follow me on Instagram @LouDobbsTonight.

A reminder, I will be interviewing President Donald Trump next week. Be sure to join us for that at this very time of day.

Up next, violent activists of Antifa and Black Lives Matter continue to ravage Democrat-run cities. What happens if they and their violence prevail? Civil Rights expert, Robert Woodson joins us. We'll take that up right after these quick messages. Please stay with us.

DOBBS: We're back with Sidney Powell, and Sidney, thank you for staying with us through the commercial break and joining us now.

We're talking -- I should explain -- because Bob Woodson, the head of the Woodson Center, Civil Rights activist, and the former head of the Criminal Justice Department of the Urban League was about to join us by Skype, and he has told our folks that he was kicked off of Skype, so we're trying to figure out what's going on there.

And we appreciate, you know, apparently there's a lot of censorship of our guests on this broadcast. I don't understand what's going on. Do you?

POWELL: No, other than we're saying things that people need to hear and other people don't want it heard.

DOBBS: This is a stunning stop. This is -- Bob Woodson is one of the most, I think, rational people in the country. He is a compendium of knowledge about racial issues in this country, part of the Civil Rights era from beginning to the present time, and an important part.

It's just troubling that this seems to happen in sort of clusters, if you will. Whether it's you, whether it's Donald Trump Jr. Whether it's Bob Woodson, the list goes on, unfortunately and you know, talking about what can we do --

POWELL: It does, and the timing is suspicious, too. Yes, the timing of it all is very suspicious.

DOBBS: And what do you mean when you say that?

POWELL: Well, I think it supports the possibility that there's a concerted effort to target conservative speakers. For Don, Jr. and I to be kicked off on the same day talking about hydroxychloroquine when as he said his tweet wasn't even substantive. Mine was retweeted by the President and it was apparently after that, that they decided mine was improper and shut down my account and locked me out because of it.

And I also can't get a blue checkmark. I'm not even sure I want one, but I have like 450,000 followers. They limit me to an increase of about a thousand followers a day, and I'm not a verified account. They refuse to verify it.

So none of it makes any sense to me other than abject discrimination, particularly against conservatives and perhaps even more against conservative women.

DOBBS: And there is no remedy for a citizen in this situation, except move your account to a competing service. Are you considering doing that?

POWELL: Well, I have an account on Parler, but frankly, Twitter dominates the market and should be required to be objective and not to influence what's being put on the platform. As long as it's not malign or profane, or anything really improper, they need to let the speech be heard.

DOBBS: Well, I happen to believe that even if it is profane, it's just a - - it's a very simple decision. Don't follow that person and don't permit them to follow you. It's all good.

POWELL: Exactly.

DOBBS: I mean, that's a very simple thing. Why do you have to manage speech?

POWELL: It is.

DOBBS: Why do you have to constrain the freedom of speech? But Jack Dorsey and I disagree about that, and as the saying goes, it is his football right now.

Sidney, we're waiting for Bob Woodson and we appreciate your staying with us to talk this thing through a bit. I look forward to talking to you again real soon. Thanks, Sid.

Up next, the President announcing a major plan to bring thousands -- thousands of U.S. troops home. Sebastian Gorka joins us with that and more right after this quick break.

And a reminder about my new book, "The Trump Century: How Our President Changed the Course of History Forever." Please preorder your copy now at thetrumpcentury.com. Frustrate the liberals. Save the Republic.

Stay with us. We'll be right back.

DOBBS: The Pentagon is moving ahead with President Trump's plan to withdraw nearly 12,000 American troops from Germany. About 5,400 of our troops will be sent to Belgium and to Italy. The others will be coming home and RINOs like Mitt Romney called the move a gift to Russia. Really?

Well. Joining us tonight is Sebastian Gorka, host of the Salem Radio program, "America First," bestselling author, former strategist to President Trump. Great to have you with us, Seb. Your reaction first to the good old Mitt Romney doing what he does so well. Just sort of snarking.

SEBASTIAN GORKA, RADIO SHOW HOST, SALEM RADIO NETWORK: I'm just -- when is Mitt Romney going to cross the aisle? I mean, he needs to scratch out that R and put a D behind his name. He is the most petulant, irrelevant politician in D.C., a man who by the way, let's not forget, Lou, wanted to be the Secretary of State in the Trump administration, but he was too incompetent and therefore couldn't get the job. Such spite, such pathetic behavior from Mitt and he really is quite amusing.

DOBBS: As I recall, he also wanted to be President and that didn't quite work out either, did it?

GORKA: No, he did not.

DOBBS: The unrest and the violence that we're seeing now -- before we go, I want to leave that one thing, one comment about that. The President said he is going to bring those troops home and he is doing so.

And I just think everyone in this country should be so proud and so grateful to him for doing so. Because there's no reason at all for those troops to be sitting there. Let me just finish and then you may do whatever you wish.

There's just no reason to have those troops there. They need to be brought home and we need to quit acting like an empire with a 1950s mentality. You may do as you wish.

GORKA: Absolutely. I'm so glad we can stay on this topic for a moment. From April 1949, when we signed the Washington Treaty, the United States defended Europe after the catastrophe of World War II, after 60 million dead. We vouched safe that continent with Article 5 of the NATO Treaty.

Now, that is no longer the case. In 1989, November, the 9th, the Cold War ended. Germany is one of the richest nations in the world, the richest in Europe and they can't even keep their promise to pay two percent of their GDP to their defense budget as they promised NATO.

I remember being lectured in the White House about how serious Germany is on their defense when Angela Merkel came to visit, and we have to remind the Chancellor and her team, this President, President Trump increased the U.S. Defense budget by a margin. The margin alone that was larger than the German defense budget.

They're not serious allies. They need to step up to the plate. And you're right, Lou, the Commander-in-Chief, Donald Trump is just keeping his promises to bring our soldiers home.

DOBBS: And right now, another aggressive act by the Communist Chinese government, 260 Chinese commercial -- most of them Chinese flagged commercial fishing vessels -- encroaching on the marine reserve of the Galapagos Islands off the coast of Ecuador.

It is an outrage. The Ecuadorians are protesting and yet, the Chinese are doing this with full knowledge of what they're doing and the consequences. This is barbaric for those vessels, that fleet to be in those waters. What should we do?

GORKA: I think we have to ensure that our allies, our friends in the region are reassured that China cannot do this. The situation with China isn't just the coronavirus, the Chinese virus. It isn't just intellectual property theft or the state of the Uighurs in those slave labor camps. It's about keeping the sea lanes of the world open for trade and for travel.

America is the only nation that can do that and does do that, and we need to send a very strong message that this will not pass. So I expect in the very near future, some very serious signal to be sent by U.S. forces in the region, a rhetorical if you will, shot across the bow of these Chinese interlopers.

DOBBS: And the deal reached between D.H.S. Secretary Chad Wolf and Katie Brown, the Governor of Oregon, to clear Ted Wheeler from the discussions and to bring in Oregon State Police and local law enforcement to protect Federal property and to maintain the order in downtown Portland, at which point, once calm is established and those local and state forces are in position, then Federal officers and agents can come home.

I think it's an intelligent resolution and I hope it works. Your thoughts?

GORKA: We have to note that this isn't just about Federal property being damaged or firebombed in 50-plus nights of violence and looting.

These riots is including Antifa and elements of Black Lives Matter, are actually attacking and firebombing buildings, when there are Federal employees inside them. Two Marshals, two members who work for D.H.S. have been blinded in recent violence by these rioters.

If the local mayor, if the local police commissioner are unprepared to protect the people of their city, somebody has to and this time it's going to be the brave officers of the Marshal Service and D.H.S. and the Federal Protective Services. This is what we have to do and it's time to take America's streets back.

DOBBS: Sebastian Gorka. Thanks, Seb. Appreciate it.

An incredible scene tonight of a fiery crash and bridge collapse in Arizona. A Union Pacific freight train derailing in Tempe, Arizona, as you see there, a large fire was ignited, and as it burned, the bridge began to collapse.

Incredibly, none of the train's crew members were injured. A bicyclist under the bridge at the moment it collapse escaped within seconds of his life.

At least 90 firefighters are battling the blaze. One witness describes the situation as a scene from hell, and we can report to you right down that there are no reports of injuries, mercifully and miraculously.

Up next, Civil Rights activist, Bob Woodson joins us on the radical left's continuing attack on America's heritage and this nation. We'll be right back.

DOBBS: We're joined now on the phone by former Civil Rights activist, Bob Woodson, the head of the Woodson Center. And Bob, I know that we were going to be talking with video here, but Skype for some reason wasn't working for you.

We'd seem to have -- I hope it's coincidental that we seem to have had a number of video problems for many of our guests here. What is your thinking tonight? It's great to have you with us even by phone.

ROBERT WOODSON, FOUNDER, WOODSON CENTER (via phone): Well, I'm pleased to be here. Well, I just heard your previous speaker talk about the kind of physical war that's going on while the cultural war continues.

As the Chair of the English Department of Rutgers University recently announced that traditional grammar is now subjective and stylistic choice, students will be encouraged to push back against bias on written accent.

She said the goal is to make writing centers linguistically diverse and decolonized spaces, and I call that intellectual profanity.

And the rule -- isn't that crazy?

DOBBS: It is crazy and the nonsense just gets bigger and bigger and more noxious it seems by the week. Rutgers is going to permit an instructor to decide what will be correct grammar and English usage for the United States and a class that will be clearly abhorrent and irrelevant.

WOODSON: Right and the no rules campaign continues and in 2011 in Virginia, the manual of students said, if students cuss a teacher out, you know, use profanity, don't suspend them. They just have a limited vocabulary.

In other words, we're just really dumbing down the culture in the name of social justice and what we are -- we believe our kids ought to be inspired by people who have prevailed in the past.

I told you just a quick story about in 1943, there were no black naval officers, Eleanor Roosevelt insisted that they train them. Well, they took 13 blacks with college education and put them through eight weeks where they were going to put white candidates -- in 16 weeks when they discovered that, they covered their windows and studied all night and when they were tested, they scored in the 90th percentile.

Believing that they cheated, they retested them individually. They scored in the 93rd percentile. They became commissioned officers.

These are the types of stories we need to be sharing with our children that the best antidote to disrespect is performance. It isn't protest or demand that the rules be changed.

DOBBS: Yes, condescension is as ugly a form of racism as any other in my book. Also, the racism of low expectations, it is all part of the same to me, slur against humanity.

The reality is our universities are made up of leftists. They're doing more indoctrinating. They have radical agendas, and I think altogether, too little education, whether it be in English, whether it be in its usage, or our literature. What in the world do these people think they're teaching? And who do they think they are teaching?

WOODSON: I don't know but --

DOBBS: They're teaching Americans.

WOODSON: They really are. But this moral and intellectual dumbing down is not occurring in the schools or wherever they send their children, I can tell you that. It's not going on in Exeter Academy or places like that. You can trust me on that one. That's the real thing.

DOBBS: You bet. Well, Bob Woodson is keeping his eye on it and bringing his voice to our broadcast every Wednesday, so please be sure to join us. We've had a few technical problems tonight. And Bob will be back with us next Wednesday and we will go as long as we want.

Thanks, Bob. Appreciate it.

A reminder before we go to break, "The Trump Century: How Our President Changed the Course of History Forever." It is already available for preorder and you can -- well, you can beat the crowds. You can preorder your book at thetrumpcentury.com, amazon.com and barnesandnoble.com.

Frustrate liberals. Save the Republic. We can use a little help, right? We're coming right back. Stay with us.

DOBBS: Here's President Trump in Midland, Texas just moments ago warning Americans about what is now the clear and present danger of radical Democrats.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: The radical Democrats want to destroy, they want to destroy our country. These people are sick. They are sick. And you better get used to hearing it because they have some real problems.

They don't love our country in any way, shape or form. They don't love our country. There's no respect for the American way of life.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: President Trump, and that's it for us tonight.

F.C.C. Commissioner Brendan Carr, Byron York, Michael Pillsbury, among our guests here tomorrow. We hope you'll join us.

Follow me on Twitter @LouDobbs. Like me on Facebook and on Instagram @LouDobbsTonight.

And a reminder, I'll be interviewing the President next week. Be sure to join us for that and tomorrow.

Good night from Sussex.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60RS-VFW1-DXMP-K2CJ-00000-00Big Tech raise advertiser, developer fees in response to digital taxes in Europe2020-09-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:23:03ZLexisNexisBig Tech raise advertiser, developer fees in response to digital taxes in EuropeTrisha Jalan

Several European countries - the UK, France, Italy and others - as well as Turkey, have in the recent past begun taxing technology companies, including the giants, with digital services taxes. Talks for developing a global framework for digital taxes fell apart after the US pulled out of negotiations earlier this year, stating that the levies discriminate against American firms and are unfair. European countries went ahead with bringing their proposed taxes into effect.

However, American companies have announced that they will pass on the additional tax burden onto their customers. This goes against the intention, since the taxes were aimed to net in revenues from giant foreign tech firms. The UK has a high threshold for taxing digital services, it's 2% levy applies to firms that have over 500 million in annual revenue, of which 25 million is taxable in the UK.

Giants have begun passing on tax to customers

Apple on Tuesday said developers will soon be charged increased levies on their revenues. In the UK, a developer will now pay an additional 2% on their revenue over and above the 20% VAT that's already applicable. Similarly, developers in Italy and France will pay another 3% over existing VATs. The remaining revenue will be split between Apple and the developer. Despite being aimed at capturing revenue from technology firms, the burden is being passed on to app makers. In addition, prices of apps and in-app purchases will increase by 7.5% - the digital tax rate Turkey is charging.

France and Italy already have had a similar framework in place. In fact, France's 3% DST was a placeholder since OECD negotiations were expected to result in a global framework. The UK's 2% digital service tax applies to "social media, search engine, or online marketplace" services for UK users.

Google is doing the same: Starting November 1, it will begin charging new levies on advertising in the UK, Austria, and Turkey. 2% will be added in the UK, 5% Turkey Regulatory Operating Costs, and a 5% digital service tax in Austria.

Amazon even announced this last month: Nearly a month ago, on August 4, Amazon said it would no longer absorb digital tax services since discussions with the UK government had ended and the tax has actually come into effect. "Now that the legislation has passed, we want to inform you that we will be increasing Referral fees, Fulfilment by Amazon (FBA) fees, monthly FBA storage fees and Multichannel Fulfilment (MCF) fees by 2% in the UK to reflect this additional cost," Amazon said. The tax became applicable for Amazon sellers starting September 1. It's worth noting that this practice has not just begun. For instance, Amazon passed on the France digital service tax, which came into effect in 2019, to customers by simply increased commission rates on businesses selling on Amazon France by 3%.

As of June 22, Austria, France, Hungary, Italy, Poland, Turkey, and the United Kingdom had implemented a DST, per Tax Foundation. The scope of activities that falls within the tax net vary by country. Facebook also passed on a 6% digital tax in Malaysia starting January 2020.

Although the levies are aimed the foreign technology firms and may even result in increased tax collections from digital economy, they may end up hurting domestic businesses in the countries. The levies will especially hit merchants and developers, say an Amazon seller with a low profit margin, the hardest.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TBC-CSC1-JDJN-613D-00000-00Big Tech, Real Estate money pours into D6 and D42018-09-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:23:03ZLexisNexisBig Tech, Real Estate money pours into D6 and D4

You can tell a lot about a politician by what they have done in previous offices a School Board member running for supervisor has a record, a supervisor running for state Senate has a record, a state legislator running for Congress has a record.

In the hierarchy of evaluating candidates for office, a past record is pretty high up.

You can learn a little (often very little) about a candidate by what they say they are going to do, particularly when those statements are intentionally vague (I support affordable housing and tenant rights). You can learn a little from that candidates endorsements, from the people who are willing to come forward and say this person will do a good job (but endorsements can also be driven by complex politics).

You can learn a bit about a candidate from looking at their campaign contributions, but only if you see a clear pattern. The fact that a lobbyist for a real-estate developer gave $500 to a candidate for supervisor doesnt mean that candidate is going to do exactly what that developer wants (especially if a lobbyist who opposes that developers projects also give $500.) Thats the reason we limit contributions to $500; no one donor is all that powerful.

But you can learn an immense amount about a candidate be looking at the $50,000, $100,000, and higher donations that independent-expenditure committees, which have no limits, are pouring into a race. People give $500 to candidates for a lot of reasons, including friendship, ideology, a need to get access Nobody puts up $50,000 for a candidate unless they are pretty confident that candidate will do what they want.

That doesnt mean bribery: Big donors give big money to candidates who are simply ideologically on their side. But it does tell you a huge amount about where that candidate will be on the issues: these mega-donors are no fools, and they dont put that kind of money into a race unless they are pretty confident they are supporting someone who will vote the way they want.

So its valuable to look at the recent Ethics Commission filings by a group called Progress SF, which is the money arm (or one of the money arms) of Big Tech and Big Real Estate.

If you arent happy with the direction of the city right now (the rent is too damn high), you can pin a lot of the blame on the people who fund Progress SF (and the elected officials who they helped put in office.)

Progress SF, which is directly connected to plutocrat Ron Conway, just dumped $100,000 into supporting Christine Johnson and Sonja Trauss in D6.

Thats big money in one district and since these IEs tend to be sued for negative attacks, its clearly aimed at Matt Haney, a School Board member and progressive candidate to replace termed-out Sup. Jane Kim.

Johnson has a record on the Planning Commission, and its generally been pro-development. Trauss has no record in office, but is a leader in the Yimby movement that encourages radical reductions in zoning laws to allow almost unlimited new housing construction.

The group also put $50,000 into a committee called Safe and Clean Sunset Coalition, which is supporting Jessica Ho for supervisor in D4. Again: Look for this group to fund attacks on Gordon Mar.

But heres whats odd about that: The largest single donation to the Big Tech and Real Estate PAC, records show, is SEIU United Healthcare Workers West, which put up $250,000 of its members money to help attack Mar.

That same union has endorsed Mar.

Whats going on there? Not clear, but UHWW leadership is close to Ahsha Safai, who wants to be board president, and Ho would be far more likely to vote for Safai than Mar.

The Ex reports that Safai has been making calls on behalf of that committee.

The second-largest donor to the super PAC is Diane Wilsey (big Real Estate) $100,000.

All told, the superPAC now has more than $400,000 to spend.

So we know that people who want Board President Ahsha Safai and want to see limited regulation of the tech industry and limited controls on real-estate dont want to see Haney or Mar elected.

This is particularly relevant because if Prop. 10 passes, the supes could be in a position to do what the real-estate industry has fought bitterly for 40 years: Impose rent controls on vacant apartments.

Whatever any of the candidates may say right now, we know what the Big Money thinks they will do. 2018 Global Data Point.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WG2-T9J1-DY19-C14N-00000-00Big tech regulation and Huawei ban put Australia in a global dance2019-07-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:23:04ZLexisNexisBig tech regulation and Huawei ban put Australia in a global dancePaul Smith

The government got kudos at the G20 for talking about online terrorism, but the government faces much bigger challenges in the tech sphere, where it looks less equipped to cope.

The Australian government risks being exposed by its lack of expertise as it gets bolder in allowing domestic positioning to intersect with the big tech issues at play globally, as legislators try to get to grips with the growing impact of technology on society.

Prime Minister Scott Morrison was hailed as having pulled off a political victory over the weekend by leading a G20 push to issue a statement putting social media giants on notice about the streaming of violent terrorist content; but finds his government on much shakier ground when it comes to the evolving dynamics of Chinese telco equipment maker Huawei's ban from participation in the National Broadband Network and mobile 5G networks.

Both issues of big tech influence and Huawei's bans hung heavily over discussions at the G20 in Japan and the Prime Minister could be advised to enjoy any praise he garners for the terrorism stance, because he is enjoying the lowest hanging fruit in the greater scheme of things.

You won't find anyone arguing too vociferously against the notion of stopping social media being used to promote terrorism, but if we're being honest, there wasn't much in the G20 statement and concurrently released Australian Taskforce to Combat Terrorist and Extreme Violent Material Online report, that hadn't already been covered off in Jacinda Ardern and Emmanuel Macron's   "Christchurch Call," international accord in May.

Censorship concern

In the context of recent police raids on journalists and broadcasters in Australia, there are some concerns already emerging about whether the spectre of the threat of terrorism will be used to censor anti-government content and suppress free speech online, but there was widespread agreement that something needs to change post-Christchurch.

Getting Donald Trump to sign on to the statement, having previously snubbed the Christchurch Call, was a good effort and not insignificant because it was largely dealing with US-based companies ... but far bigger issues abound surrounding the influence of big tech on society, which could do with some global unity.

The ACCC has just delivered the final report of its digital platforms inquiry to the government, looking at potential new legislative measures to curb the power of Google, Facebook and its smaller peers like Twitter in the media and advertising industries.

The strength of the government's response to these suggestions will tell us more about the resolve to combat the perils of market dominance, fake news and societal manipulation, than a chorus of furious agreement on terrorism.

The issue of unrealistically low local tax bills in jurisdictions around the world will not be addressed in the ACCC report, but is the kind of problem that can only realistically be handled by G20-style co-ordination, rather than individual leaders talking tough to impress voters in their respective countries.

Then we look at issues surrounding the breakneck pace of artificial intelligence and automation of various kinds, and see that there is still essentially a vacuum in political leadership, both in Australia and globally, on issues that will significantly reshape society as we know it.

We've seen what happens when big tech is left to make its own rules, so the world should be calling out for tech savvy political leaders to push informed debate about such big issues forward.

Huawei remains a different kettle of fish entirely, as it looks increasingly possible that Australia could find itself taking the toughest stance in the world against the Chinese giant.

The US put Huawei on a blacklist back in May, which meant that, in addition to the kind of telco equipment bans that Australia has in place, it forbade US companies from selling its products to Huawei.

Crucially this included Google, with its Android operating system being the core nervous system of Huawei's increasingly popular smartphones.

Concessions in US

But concessions given by the US President on Sunday on the blanket ban against Huaweihas the government scrambling to understand the wider implications.

The UK has already taken a softer stance than Australia towards Huawei with regards to its 5G networks, so a change in the US position would leave the Australian government looking very exposed.

Huawei showed last week that it is ready to take the gloves off to punish the Australian government, by hitting it in its exposed policy soft spots.

It launched a broadside about the failures of the government's National Broadband Network policy, which aside from advocating for its own 5G interests, hit the nail on the head with some hard truths about a policy the government cannot afford to change without a significant political climb-down.

Huawei said it could help ISPs like Vodafone, Optus and Telstra build out 5G networks into more parts of Australia and provide a compelling alternative to crawling NBN fixed wireless services.

Nothing to lose

It has nothing to lose with the Australian government, so can shoot from the hip to both attempt to embarrass the government into concessions and show other governments around the world that it won't leave quietly if they try and lock the doors.

With or without Huawei's assistance, its idea of private competition to the Coalition's underwhelming technology patchwork NBN looks like a good idea to the thousands of Australians who will currently be forced to pay through the nose for anything remotely resembling internationally competitive broadband speeds.

It would be disastrous for the NBN's business model however, so is incredibly unlikely, but would be a big tech decision this government could take to improve the experience of its citizens.

If the last week shows the government anything it is that it is best served getting on the front foot and talking publicly about big tech issues. Having spent the last few years avoiding the topic like the plague however, it remains questionable whether it has the capacity to move beyond the surface level and easy victories.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VSN-9861-F0J6-J491-00000-00Big tech regulation must learn from history, Microsoft urges2019-04-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:23:03ZLexisNexisCOMPUTERSPg. 19Big tech regulation must learn from history, Microsoft urgesPaul Smith

The push to better regulate big tech following the Christchurch massacre must focus on answering the big ethical questions of our age, Microsoft president Brad Smith says, as governments globally grapple with the rise of artificial intelligence and the reach of the tech titans.

In a wide-ranging interview with The Australian Financial Review as part of a trip to the region to meet with government and industry leaders, Smith warned against introducing regulation hastily - be it to address hate speech on the internet, or break up the tech companies.

Upon becoming Microsoft's general counsel in 2002 Smith effectively had to pursue peace treaties with state governments across the US and 27 governments around the world and he said one thing became clear - splitting up tech companies when they perceivably became too powerful was not the way to go.

"I studied a century's worth of antitrust experience going back to the break up of Standard Oil in the United States in 1916, and asked what lessons we can learn," Smith recalls.

"One of the clearest things was that breaking up companies had not typically been the approach that the government ended up pursuing, because there were more nuanced and frankly more sophisticated approaches that can serve consumers and the public more effectively."

In the US, tech companies such as Google, Facebook and Amazon could face the prospect of forcibly separating their operations if would-be Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren is successful.

The thrust of Warren's argument is that platforms like Google and Amazon should not be allowed to own the companies that operate on them, lest they give them an unfair advantage against rivals.

In 2001 the US government Department of Justice took on Microsoft, saying it was abusing its monopoly position by bundling its Internet Explorer browser with its Windows operating system, to the detriment of high-profile rivals like Netscape.

After originally winning an order to break up Microsoft's operations along product lines, the case was overturned on appeal and eventually the government reached a settlement with Microsoft in which it agreed to open up access to its platforms to rivals and give regulators transparency to show it was happening.

"We, too, were in this situation where people were talking about what it meant to be both in the platform business and to be in the applications business, and ultimately the best approach was found to be not break up the company, but to some degree pry some products apart with regulatory controls," Smith says. "There were regulatory responsibilities that were put in place with respect to the platform and over the course of 20 years, I think most antitrust authorities would look at it and regard it as a success story."

In Australia attempts are also under way to police the tech sector via the competition regulator's inquiry into the oversized power of global tech platforms.

Last week the government also proposed introducing jail sentences for social media company executives, as well as financial penalties, if they do not act to remove extremist content quickly enough, in response to the Christchurch terror attack.

Smith conceded international efforts to rein in the power of huge platforms warranted serious consideration, saying he understood why the Prime Minister would suggest criminal sanctions and why he wanted to act quickly.

But he says talk of jailing executives sounds like it was born more out of frustration with the social media companies, than actually being the best long-term approach to effect change.

"I think that governments do need to start moving faster on technology issues, but one always needs to be very careful not to move faster than the speed of thought," Smith says.

"Not surprisingly, I'm not going to be the foremost advocate of sending myself or my colleagues in other companies to prison. I think that might have a chilling effect on international travel, that actually helps us understand what the world's people need from our products."

He believed global industry-wide initiatives and more nuanced legislation would better tackle the growing displeasure at the negative impacts of big tech on society.

Smith's team had debated at length whether it would be inappropriate or offensive for him to continue with his visit to Australia in the wake of the Christchurch attack, but decided, in consultation with New Zealand authorities, that it was important to have the conversation about the use of technology publicly.

"We spent a lot of time trying to pull our thoughts together, but we knew it had to start with the sense that we know that words are not enough," Smith says.

"We need to acknowledge that however technology might have helped in some respects, it didn't work well enough, so let's start by acknowledging that first principle. We have to figure out a way for it to work better in these kinds of situations."

Over the weekend Facebook chief executive Mark Zuckerberg came out on the front foot following the government's move to legislate the platforms and called for more regulation worldwide on everything from harmful, violent content on the internet to election integrity and privacy.

Smith is one of the technology industry's most respected figures, having joined Microsoft in 1993 as a legal executive and helping pilot it through its lengthy antitrust battles with the US government. He has gone on to be viewed as a de facto ambassador for the sector at large, gaining particular prominence when speaking out about US government attempts to increase its powers to access private data.

Aside from its CEO Satya Nadella, Smith has become the face of Microsoft and is often the man charged with meeting world leaders. He met New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern on his recent visit, and often finds himself in the White House.

While he met government staffers in Australia, it is understood that scheduling conflicts meant he was unable to meet Scott Morrison.

With artificial intelligence at the core of most of Microsoft's main products, he has taken a vocal role in trying to urge governments around the world to develop an ethical framework for regulating what computers can be allowed to decide.

Aside from discussions about what the future of the workplace looks like in the era of AI-led automation, these concerns include the ethics of AI-based warfare and the societal impacts that could emerge from the rampant adoption of facial recognition software in CCTV cameras around the world.

In the US a bipartisan bill, backed by Microsoft, has been introduced to legislate the commercial applications of facial recognition technology. This includes requiring companies to get explicit user consent before collecting facial recognition data, and preventing them from sharing the data with third parties.

It is aimed to address fears that citizens could find themselves in an Orwellian world whereby all their moves are recorded and available to governments and corporations.

"We need to be principled in how we build it, test it, sell it and support it and we've identified the issues that need to be addressed around bias and discrimination, around commercial privacy and the rights that people have, around what it could mean for our democratic freedoms if it's misused and abused," Smith told the audience at a Microsoft event in Sydney.

"We don't want to see a race to the bottom where people just scoop up deals based on technology that's not ready, with customers in countries that may not live up to human rights and democratic ideals and see the market go in that direction. Ultimately, this is an issue for every country ... the technology is global ... in many ways the ethical principles at stake really sit on a foundation of centuries of philosophy ... Countries like Australia that have their intellectual roots in one tradition but have close relationships with a region that is started in another, have a unique opportunity to contribute to the global conversation we need."

Asked about his unique role in dealing with world leaders of all political colours, and particularly the challenge of dealing with a unique character like US President Donald Trump, Smith shows his powers of diplomacy to be predictably strong.

He says the trait shared by the best leaders in his dealings is a curiosity about what can be done, and what could be done better in the future, and that this did not necessarily have anything to do with partisan lines.

"One lesson I've learned is even if you don't agree with the ideas that someone is putting forward, it's really important to understand the problems that are motivating their concerns," Smith says.

"One of the things that's challenging around the world today is oftentimes in the world of politics in every country, people are both talking past each other and arguing about competing ideas, without building a common understanding of the areas where they might have a shared view, namely, 'what is the problem here?"'

Minus an express exemption, there could be legal questions about new laws imposing liability that might conflict with Section 230 ...

urn:contentItem:5WD0-KWT1-DYRJ-03TH-00000-00Big Tech Regulation Raises Numerous Legal Questions, CRS Says2019-06-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:23:03ZLexisNexisCAPITOL HILLBig Tech Regulation Raises Numerous Legal Questions, CRS Says

As Congress mulls new regulatory approaches to major tech companies, it might want to look at creating an exemption to Communications Decency Act Section 230 to hold service providers liable for publishing or restricting certain kinds of content, the Congressional Research Service reported. Minus an express exemption, there could be legal questions about new laws imposing liability that might conflict with Section 230 general immunity, CRS said Monday. It said such rules might also have First Amendment issues. It said any move to a comprehensive federal data protection law might need to weigh whether to be prescriptive or outcome-based, the definition of protected information and the role of the FTC or another federal enforcement agency. It said reclassification of ISPs as common carriers could create legal uncertainty about data protection obligations since they no longer would be under FTC jurisdiction. It said antitrust action against such tech companies also would raise complicated legal questions such as market definitions for dynamic technology industries. Since many tech companies provide services for free, demonstrating a monopoly could be difficult, CRS said.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XGM-6CW1-DY91-K374-00000-00Big tech reigns in Europe, despite laws;North American, EU lawmakers warn of tougher antitrust rules2019-11-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:23:04ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. B5Big tech reigns in Europe, despite lawsNorth American, EU lawmakers warn of tougher antitrust rulesAdam Satariano The New York TimesLONDON

Richard Stables should have felt vindicated when the European Union announced a $2.7-billion (U.S.) fine in 2017 against Google for breaking antitrust laws. He had raised alarms about the search giant's power for years.

But rather than feel victorious, Stables felt resigned. His company, Kelkoo, once a leading online shopping destination in Europe, was crushed by Google's competing service while the case was under way.

"It took basically eight years to get something done," Stables, 50, said in an interview at his London office. "That's a complete disaster."

Regulators in Brussels have been heralded as the world's leading tech industry watchdogs. But Stables and other veterans of the Continent's antitrust battles are telling U.S. authorities, who are investigating Google, Amazon, Apple and Facebook, something else: there is a lot to learn from Europe's mistakes.

Antitrust investigations in Europe have taken years to complete, in part because company lawyers use stalling techniques that give the tech giants added time to squeeze out rivals, according to companies, lawyers and consumer groups involved in the cases against Google. The inquiries have centred on single aspects of the companies, like Google shopping, rather than their entire business. And once regulators have stepped in, the penalties have focused on headline-grabbing fines rather than structural changes that would restore competitive balance.

Europe's regulators have taken antitrust actions against numerous tech companies. None have faced more scrutiny over the past decade than Google - yet critics say it has emerged virtually unscathed. Its revenue rose to $137 billion in 2018, up from $23.7 billion in 2009, when rivals filed the first antitrust complaint.

"You have to move fast and impose remedies that actually bite," said Thomas Vinje, an antitrust lawyer who represented companies against Google in Europe.

In recent weeks, authorities in the United States and Europe have signalled that they believe tougher antitrust enforcement is necessary.

Margrethe Vestager, the top antitrust regulator in the European Union, who has fined Google more than $9 billion since 2017 for antitrust violations, is pushing new approaches. She has invoked a rarely applied rule, known as "interim measures." It acts like a cease-and-desist order, forcing a company to stop acting a certain way until an antitrust investigation can be completed.

Another idea floated by Vestager, whose office is investigating Amazon and exploring cases against Facebook and Apple, would shift the burden of proof in cases involving large tech companies. It would require them to show how their behaviour helps consumers. Usually, regulators must demonstrate harm to consumers.

In the United States, Makan Delrahim, head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, recently said remedies as far-reaching as breaking up the companies were "perfectly on the table."

"If the American authorities learn from Europe's experience, they have a big opportunity" to restore competition, said Shivaun Raff, a co-founder of Foundem, a price comparison website that filed the original complaint against Google in 2009.

The Kelkoo experience demonstrates the challenge.

Founded in 1999, the website was an early online success story in Europe. Kelkoo became a top destination for consumers in countries like Britain, France and the Netherlands to compare products listed on different websites.

But in February 2011, the traffic that Google sent to Kelkoo and others tumbled. Google had a similar shopping service and was now putting its own listings at the top of search queries.

"It basically smashed the market," said Stables, the company's chief executive. "Our free traffic that came from Google dropped by 92 per cent in two or three years."

Google, which has denied wrongdoing, declined to comment.

The European Commission issued its final ruling against Google in the shopping case in 2017, but rivals say the company still has not properly applied remedies outlined by regulators to create a level playing field for websites like Kelkoo.

In 2018, the commission fined Google a record 4.34 billion euros, worth about $4.8 billion today, for illegally using its Android mobile phone software to block rival search engines. Remedies in that case, including giving customers more search engines to use, are still being argued over.

In a third case, related to an online advertising practice that Google has since ended, European authorities fined Google 1.5 billion euros, or about $1.7 billion.

Google is appealing all three decisions, leaving open the possibility that the fines could be voided.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XGM-6X41-JDH1-C19V-00000-00Big tech reigns in Europe, despite laws;North American, EU lawmakers warn of tougher antitrust rules2019-11-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:23:03ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. B6Big tech reigns in Europe, despite lawsNorth American, EU lawmakers warn of tougher antitrust rulesAdam Satariano The New York Times

Richard Stables should have felt vindicated when the European Union announced a $2.7-billion (U.S.) fine in 2017 against Google for breaking antitrust laws. He had raised alarms about the search giant's power for years.

But rather than feel victorious, Stables felt resigned. His company, Kelkoo, once a leading online shopping destination in Europe, was crushed by Google's competing service while the case was under way.

"It took basically eight years to get something done," Stables, 50, said in an interview at his London office. "That's a complete disaster."

Regulators in Brussels have been heralded as the world's leading tech industry watchdogs. But Stables and other veterans of the Continent's antitrust battles are telling U.S. authorities, who are investigating Google, Amazon, Apple and Facebook, something else: there is a lot to learn from Europe's mistakes.

Antitrust investigations in Europe have taken years to complete, in part because company lawyers use stalling techniques that give the tech giants added time to squeeze out rivals, according to companies, lawyers and consumer groups involved in the cases against Google. The inquiries have centred on single aspects of the companies, like Google shopping, rather than their entire business. And once regulators have stepped in, the penalties have focused on headline-grabbing fines rather than structural changes that would restore competitive balance.

Europe's regulators have taken antitrust actions against numerous tech companies. None have faced more scrutiny over the past decade than Google - yet critics say it has emerged virtually unscathed. Its revenue rose to $137 billion in 2018, up from $23.7 billion in 2009, when rivals filed the first antitrust complaint.

"You have to move fast and impose remedies that actually bite," said Thomas Vinje, an antitrust lawyer who represented companies against Google in Europe.

In recent weeks, authorities in the United States and Europe have signalled that they believe tougher antitrust enforcement is necessary.

Margrethe Vestager, the top antitrust regulator in the European Union, who has fined Google more than $9 billion since 2017 for antitrust violations, is pushing new approaches. She has invoked a rarely applied rule, known as "interim measures." It acts like a cease-and-desist order, forcing a company to stop acting a certain way until an antitrust investigation can be completed.

Another idea floated by Vestager, whose office is investigating Amazon and exploring cases against Facebook and Apple, would shift the burden of proof in cases involving large tech companies. It would require them to show how their behaviour helps consumers. Usually, regulators must demonstrate harm to consumers.

In the United States, Makan Delrahim, head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, recently said remedies as far-reaching as breaking up the companies were "perfectly on the table."

"If the American authorities learn from Europe's experience, they have a big opportunity" to restore competition, said Shivaun Raff, a co-founder of Foundem, a price comparison website that filed the original complaint against Google in 2009.

The Kelkoo experience demonstrates the challenge.

Founded in 1999, the website was an early online success story in Europe. Kelkoo became a top destination for consumers in countries like Britain, France and the Netherlands to compare products listed on different websites.

But in February 2011, the traffic that Google sent to Kelkoo and others tumbled. Google had a similar shopping service and was now putting its own listings at the top of search queries.

"It basically smashed the market," said Stables, the company's chief executive. "Our free traffic that came from Google dropped by 92 per cent in two or three years."

Google, which has denied wrongdoing, declined to comment.

The European Commission issued its final ruling against Google in the shopping case in 2017, but rivals say the company still has not properly applied remedies outlined by regulators to create a level playing field for websites like Kelkoo.

In 2018, the commission fined Google a record 4.34 billion euros, worth about $4.8 billion today, for illegally using its Android mobile phone software to block rival search engines. Remedies in that case, including giving customers more search engines to use, are still being argued over.

In a third case, related to an online advertising practice that Google has since ended, European authorities fined Google 1.5 billion euros, or about $1.7 billion.

Google is appealing all three decisions, leaving open the possibility that the fines could be voided.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:6059-N0F1-JD33-J3G7-00000-00Big Tech Resilient Despite Covid-19 With Digital Transformation A Long-Term Opportunity2020-05-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:23:04ZLexisNexisBig Tech Resilient Despite Covid-19 With Digital Transformation A Long-Term Opportunity

Q120 results for the Big Tech companies have shown their resilience to Covid-19, with all showing growth. As expected, Amazon was the main winner, but faces headwinds in terms of costs and regulatory scrutiny. In terms of business areas, cloud emerges as the big winner. Q2 remains a worry, but in the longer-term, tech companies will benefit from the acceleration of digital transformation trends.

Key View Q120 results for the Big Tech companies have shown their resilience to Covid-19, with all showing growth As expected, Amazon was the main winner, but faces headwinds in terms of costs and regulatory scrutiny In terms of business areas, cloud emerges as the big winner Q2 remains a worry, but in the longer-term, tech companies will benefit from the acceleration of digital transformation trends After Netflix, the main five US tech companies - Apple, Amazon, Google, Facebook and Microsoft - have all reported their quarterly results, and all showed growth in the quarter despite the impact of Covid-19. The pandemic only started to impact their results in March, meaning that the first two months of the quarter were considered normal, and this is why they remain uncertain about their Q2 performance, despite seeing some encouraging signs in April for their businesses.

Growth Across The Board

Quarterly Revenues (USDbn) And Yearly Growth (%), Q120

Source: Companies, Fitch Solutions

Amazon was the big winner, seeing revenues grew by 26% yoy to USD75.5bn. People are staying at home, and Amazon benefits from being the e-commerce leader and being able to deliver a range of products to customers whose movements are restricted. Amazon also benefits from being the cloud leader, with people working more from home or using online services (such as Netflix and Zoom, both of which use AWS), and its cloud revenues hit over USD10bn for the first time. But this comes at a cost, with the company reporting that Covid-19 will mean expenses will grow by USD4bn, more or less equal to its profit. Amazon has always reinvested the majority of its profits into its business, so this strategy should not be a surprise, but it highlights how much bigger Amazon's workforce is compared to its rivals, and how reliant it is on it to carry out its services. Its strength this quarter also highlights how reliant we are as customers on Amazon, and we believe this will mean greater regulatory scrutiny for the company going forward. The situation in France, where Amazon had to close its warehouses after a dispute on workers' safety (but still able to provide services to French customers through its other European warehouses), shows the conflation of the two key issues the company will need to face.Apple only saw its revenues grew by 0.5% y-o-y, but considering the headwinds it faced, this was still a strong performance, especially in the latter part of the quarter. Unlike its rivals, it saw the first impact of Covid-19 early in February, when the disease first hit China, and that demand shock was followed by a supply shock in China and subsequently by a demand shock in the rest of the world, with the company closing its stores. The services segment continues to be a key driver, representing almost a quarter of revenues in Q1, and is the crucial part of its long-term strategy. Q2 is usually Apple's worst quarter of the year, and lower sales of hardware are expected despite the launch of the iPhone SE, so services will once again be the main growth driver between April and June.Tech companies have reported greater usage than usual because more people stayed at home. Facebook almost hit 3bn monthly customers across all its platforms, whereas Netflix added close to 16mn customers in the quarter. Greater usage does not necessarily mean monetisation, but digital advertising trends have not suffered as much as might have been expected, whereas streaming remains a growth market with strong potential.

Cloud A Big Winner

Yearly Revenue Growth (%), Q120

Source: Companies, Fitch Solutions

Cloud was, however, the big winner this quarter, with more people working from home, and it highlights the first stage of what we consider to be the acceleration of the digital transformation trends we had highlighted for 2030 and 2050. Both Microsoft - saying they had seen two years' worth of transformation in two months - and Google - seeing a greater movement towards digital services in sectors such as education, medicine, shopping and entertainment - picked up on these trends, and this is where tech companies can continue to see long-term growth as we are only seeing the start of that movement. Q2 remains a short-term worry, though, because of the uncertainty of Covid-19, and how long its impact will last in the market. Microsoft issued a wider guidance as usual, whereas Apple chose not to do so, citing those uncertainties. There is some hope that certain markets are starting to stabilise, or at least enter a pattern where customers are used to the new normal, but it must be highlighted that while tech companies are in a strong position, they can nonetheless be negatively impacted by worsening macroeconomic conditions.
