Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60G9-FV91-JCSC-J2WX-00000-00Big Tech results grab spotlight after Congress hearing...2020-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:23:03ZLexisNexisNEWSBig Tech results grab spotlight after Congress hearing...

Four of the United States' big tech firms, accounting for nearly a fifth of the S&P 500's total value, report results on Thursday on the heels of a bruising Congressional hearing to look into alleged abuse of their global dominance. It will be the first ti... Four of the United States' big...

Four of the United States' big tech firms, accounting for nearly a fifth of the S&P 500's total value, report results on Thursday on the heels of a bruising Congressional hearing to look into alleged abuse of their global dominance. It will be the first ti...

Four of the United States' big tech firms, accounting for nearly a fifth of the S&P 500's total value, report results on Thursday on the heels of a bruising Congressional hearing to look into alleged abuse of their global dominance. It will be the first time Apple Inc, Amazon.com Inc , Alphabet Inc and Facebook Inc post financial results on the same day and investors wonder if they can deliver enough to extend a rally that has been central to Wall Street's recovery since March. Deemed "stay-at-home" winners as millions of Americans were ordered indoors to contain the Covid-19 pandemic, shares in the big tech players have scaled record highs at a time when the benchmark S&P 500 is up less than 1 percent on the year. But with many of Apple's stores still closed and Amazon's e-commerce costs soaring, there are question marks, and some on Wall Street argue that stock prices for all four have been bloated beyond rational valuations. Shares in Microsoft Corp fell 4.4 percent the day after its report last week, despite better-than-expected cloud revenue and its stock is now nearly flat on the month after hitting an all-time high in early July. "It's simply momentum," Leo Kelly, founder of Verdence Capital Advisors, told the Reuters Global Markets Forum, ahead of the results, due after the closing bell. "When you have stocks looking like they're moving into a bubble, what you don't know is how far it will go. You can't just look at valuation and say 'it's going to fall.' It can go anywhere and the risk is becoming extremely, extremely high." Threats Alphabet's Google and Facebook took particularly sharp jabs on Wednesday from Democrats and Republicans who say they have crippled smaller rivals in the quest for market share, the latest blows in an increasingly threatening regulatory landscape. Apple's headache is a slowdown in hardware sales as the world slides into recession, with analysts predicting pandemic disruptions will see revenue fall about 3 percent and the iPhone business by nearly 14 percent. Similarly, Facebook and Google are contending with a collapse in marketing spending. Refinitiv analysts estimate Facebook could generate its slowest revenue growth - around 3 percent - since it became a public company. Still, despite the surge in stock prices raising the specter of another tech bubble - Amazon is up 64 percent this year and the others 13 percent-29 percent - analysts remain confident about the longer-term growth prospects for the four companies. "Even the bears will say that these are fantastic companies and they are not going to stop being fantastic," said Nicholas Colas, co-founder of DataTrek Research. "The unifying factor is they have the ability to both grow and control their cost structures through the pandemic. That is always a good place to start from when you have a downturn."

urn:contentItem:60G9-TPD1-DYWP-R047-00000-00Big Tech results move center stage after Congressional bruising2020-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:23:03ZLexisNexisBUSINESSBig Tech results move center stage after Congressional bruising

REUTERS: Four of the United States' big tech firms, accounting for nearly a fifth of the S&P 500's total value, report results on Thursday on the heels of a bruising Congressional hearing to look into alleged abuse of their global dominance. It will be the first time Apple Inc, Amazon.com Inc, Alphabet Inc and Facebook Inc post financial results on the same day and investors wonder if they can deliver enough to extend a rally that has been central to Wall Street's recovery since March. Deemed "stay-at-home" winners as millions of Americans were ordered indoors to contain the COVID-19 pandemic, shares in the big tech players have scaled record highs at a time when the benchmark S&P 500 is up less than 1per cent on the year. But with many of Apple's stores still closed and Amazon's e-commerce costs soaring, there are question marks, and some on Wall Street argue that stock prices for all four have been bloated beyond rational valuations.

Shares in Microsoft Corp fell 4.4per cent the day after its report last week despite better-than-expected cloud revenue, and its stock is now nearly flat on the month after hitting an all-time high in early July. "It's simply momentum," Leo Kelly, founder of Verdence Capital Advisors, told the Reuters Global Markets Forum ahead of the results, due after the closing bell. "When you have stocks looking like they're moving into a bubble, what you don't know is how far it will go. You can't just look at valuation and say 'it's going to fall.' It can go anywhere and the risk is becoming extremely, extremely high." Graphic: Big Tech gets bigger - https://fingfx.thomsonreuters.com/gfx/mkt/qzjvqwyxzvx/Pastedper cent20imageper cent201596039504826.png THREATS Alphabet's Google and Facebook took particularly sharp jabs on Wednesday from Democrats and Republicans who say they have crippled smaller rivals in the quest for market share, the latest blows in an increasingly threatening regulatory landscape. Amazon rose about 1per cent on Thursday, while Apple, Alphabet and Facebook were close to unchanged. Apple's headache is a slowdown in hardware sales as the world slides into recession, with analysts predicting pandemic disruptions will reduce revenue about 3per cent and depress the iPhone business by nearly 14per cent. Similarly, Facebook and Google are contending with a collapse in marketing spending. Refinitiv analysts estimate Facebook could generate its slowest revenue growth - around 3per cent - since it became a public company. Despite the stock surge raising the specter of another tech bubble, with Amazon up 64per cent this year and the others up between 13per cent and 29per cent, investors are betting the deep-pocketed companies will emerge from the coronavirus crisis stronger than their smaller competitors. "Even the bears will say that these are fantastic companies and they are not going to stop being fantastic," said Nicholas Colas, co-founder of DataTrek Research. "The unifying factor is they have the ability to both grow and control their cost structures through the pandemic. That is always a good place to start from when you have a downturn." (Reporting by Sagarika Jaisinghani and Neha Malara in Bengaluru; additional reporting by Lisa Pauline Mattackal in Bengaluru and Noel Randewich in San Francisco; Editing by Richard Chang) - Reuters

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60G9-FV11-F07F-81P2-00000-00Big Tech results move center stage after Congressional bruising2020-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:23:04ZLexisNexisNEWSBig Tech results move center stage after Congressional bruising

Four of the United States’ big tech firms, accounting for nearly a fifth of the S&P 500’s total value, report results on Thursday on the heels of a bruising Congressional hearing to look into alleged abuse of their global dominance. It will be the first ti... Four of the United States’ big tech firms,...

Four of the United States’ big tech firms, accounting for nearly a fifth of the S&P 500’s total value, report results on Thursday on the heels of a bruising Congressional hearing to look into alleged abuse of their global dominance. It will be the first ti...

Four of the United States’ big tech firms, accounting for nearly a fifth of the S&P 500’s total value, report results on Thursday on the heels of a bruising Congressional hearing to look into alleged abuse of their global dominance. It will be the first time Apple Inc , Amazon.com Inc , Alphabet Inc and Facebook Inc post financial results on the same day and investors wonder if they can deliver enough to extend a rally that has been central to Wall Street’s recovery since March. Deemed “stay-at-home” winners as millions of Americans were ordered indoors to contain the COVID-19 pandemic, shares in the big tech players have scaled record highs at a time when the benchmark S&P 500 is up less than 1% on the year. But with many of Apple’s stores still closed and Amazon’s e-commerce costs soaring, there are question marks, and some on Wall Street argue that stock prices for all four have been bloated beyond rational valuations. Shares in Microsoft Corp fell 4.4% the day after its report last week, despite better-than-expected cloud revenue and its stock is now nearly flat on the month after hitting an all-time high in early July. “It’s simply momentum,” Leo Kelly, founder of Verdence Capital Advisors, told the Reuters Global Markets Forum, ahead of the results, due after the closing bell. “When you have stocks looking like they’re moving into a bubble, what you don’t know is how far it will go. You can’t just look at valuation and say ‘it’s going to fall.’ It can go anywhere and the risk is becoming extremely, extremely high.” THREATS Alphabet’s Google and Facebook took particularly sharp jabs on Wednesday from Democrats and Republicans who say they have crippled smaller rivals in the quest for market share, the latest blows in an increasingly threatening regulatory landscape. Apple’s headache is a slowdown in hardware sales as the world slides into recession, with analysts predicting pandemic disruptions will see revenue fall about 3% and the iPhone business by nearly 14%. Similarly, Facebook and Google are contending with a collapse in marketing spending. Refinitiv analysts estimate Facebook could generate its slowest revenue growth – around 3% – since it became a public company. Still, despite the surge in stock prices raising the specter of another tech bubble – Amazon is up 64% this year and the others 13%-29% – analysts remain confident about the longer-term growth prospects for the four companies. “Even the bears will say that these are fantastic companies and they are not going to stop being fantastic,” said Nicholas Colas, co-founder of DataTrek Research. “The unifying factor is they have the ability to both grow and control their cost structures through the pandemic. That is always a good place to start from when you have a downturn.” Disclaimer: This post has been auto-published from an agency feed without any modifications to the text and has not been reviewed by an editor

urn:contentItem:60G9-FV21-F07F-816M-00000-00Big Tech results move center stage after Congressional bruising2020-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:23:04ZLexisNexisNEWSBig Tech results move center stage after Congressional bruisingSagarika Jaisinghani, Neha Malara

(Reuters) - Four of the United States’ big tech firms, accounting for nearly a fifth of the S&P 500’s total value, report results on Thursday on the heels of a bruising Congressional hearing to look into alleged abuse of their global dominance. FILE PHOTO:... (Reuters) - Four of the United States’ big tech firms, accounting for nearly...

(Reuters) - Four of the United States’ big tech firms, accounting for nearly a fifth of the S&P 500’s total value, report results on Thursday on the heels of a bruising Congressional hearing to look into alleged abuse of their global dominance. FILE PHOTO:...

(Reuters) - Four of the United States’ big tech firms, accounting for nearly a fifth of the S&P 500’s total value, report results on Thursday on the heels of a bruising Congressional hearing to look into alleged abuse of their global dominance. FILE PHOTO: The logos of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google are seen in a combination photo from Reuters files. REUTERS/File Photos/File Photo It will be the first time Apple Inc ( AAPL.O ), Amazon.com Inc ( AMZN.O ), Alphabet Inc ( GOOGL.O ) and Facebook Inc ( FB.O ) post financial results on the same day and investors wonder if they can deliver enough to extend a rally that has been central to Wall Street’s recovery since March. Deemed “stay-at-home” winners as millions of Americans were ordered indoors to contain the COVID-19 pandemic, shares in the big tech players have scaled record highs at a time when the benchmark S&P 500 .SPX is up less than 1% on the year. But with many of Apple’s stores still closed and Amazon’s e-commerce costs soaring, there are question marks, and some on Wall Street argue that stock prices for all four have been bloated beyond rational valuations. Shares in Microsoft Corp ( MSFT.O ) fell 4.4% the day after its report last week, despite better-than-expected cloud revenue and its stock is now nearly flat on the month after hitting an all-time high in early July. “It’s simply momentum,” Leo Kelly, founder of Verdence Capital Advisors, told the Reuters Global Markets Forum, ahead of the results, due after the closing bell. “When you have stocks looking like they’re moving into a bubble, what you don’t know is how far it will go. You can’t just look at valuation and say ‘it’s going to fall.’ It can go anywhere and the risk is becoming extremely, extremely high.” THREATS Alphabet’s Google and Facebook took particularly sharp jabs on Wednesday from Democrats and Republicans who say they have crippled smaller rivals in the quest for market share, the latest blows in an increasingly threatening regulatory landscape. Apple’s headache is a slowdown in hardware sales as the world slides into recession, with analysts predicting pandemic disruptions will see revenue fall about 3% and the iPhone business by nearly 14%. Similarly, Facebook and Google are contending with a collapse in marketing spending. Refinitiv analysts estimate Facebook could generate its slowest revenue growth - around 3% - since it became a public company. Still, despite the surge in stock prices raising the specter of another tech bubble - Amazon is up 64% this year and the others 13%-29% - analysts remain confident about the longer-term growth prospects for the four companies. “Even the bears will say that these are fantastic companies and they are not going to stop being fantastic,” said Nicholas Colas, co-founder of DataTrek Research. “The unifying factor is they have the ability to both grow and control their cost structures through the pandemic. That is always a good place to start from when you have a downturn.” Reporting by Sagarika Jaisinghani and Neha Malara in Bengaluru; additional reporting by Lisa Pauline Mattackal in Bengaluru and Noel Randewich in San Francisco; Editing by Patrick Graham, Bernard Orr

(Reuters) - Four of the United States’ big tech firms, accounting for nearly a fifth of the S&P 500’s total value, report results on Thursday on the heels of a bruising Congressional hearing to look into alleged abuse of their global dominance. It will be the first time Apple Inc ( AAPL.O ), Amazon.com Inc ( AMZN.O ), Alphabet Inc ( GOOGL.O ) and Facebook Inc ( FB.O ) post financial results on the same day and investors wonder if they can deliver enough to extend a rally that has been central to Wall Street’s recovery since March. Deemed "stay-at-home" winners as millions of Americans were ordered indoors to contain the COVID-19 pandemic, shares in the big tech players have scaled record highs at a time when the benchmark S&P 500 .SPX is up less than 1% on the year. But with many of Apple’s stores still closed and Amazon’s e-commerce costs soaring, there are question marks, and some on Wall Street argue that stock prices for all four have been bloated beyond rational valuations. Shares in Microsoft Corp ( MSFT.O ) fell 4.4% the day after its report last week, despite better-than-expected cloud revenue and its stock is now nearly flat on the month after hitting an all-time high in early July. “It’s simply momentum,” Leo Kelly, founder of Verdence Capital Advisors, told the Reuters Global Markets Forum, ahead of the results, due after the closing bell. “When you have stocks looking like they’re moving into a bubble, what you don’t know is how far it will go. You can’t just look at valuation and say ‘it’s going to fall.’ It can go anywhere and the risk is becoming extremely, extremely high.” THREATS Alphabet’s Google and Facebook took particularly sharp jabs on Wednesday from Democrats and Republicans who say they have crippled smaller rivals in the quest for market share, the latest blows in an increasingly threatening regulatory landscape. Apple’s headache is a slowdown in hardware sales as the world slides into recession, with analysts predicting pandemic disruptions will see revenue fall about 3% and the iPhone business by nearly 14%. Similarly, Facebook and Google are contending with a collapse in marketing spending. Refinitiv analysts estimate Facebook could generate its slowest revenue growth - around 3% - since it became a public company. Still, despite the surge in stock prices raising the specter of another tech bubble - Amazon is up 64% this year and the others 13%-29% - analysts remain confident about the longer-term growth prospects for the four companies. “Even the bears will say that these are fantastic companies and they are not going to stop being fantastic,” said Nicholas Colas, co-founder of DataTrek Research. “The unifying factor is they have the ability to both grow and control their cost structures through the pandemic. That is always a good place to start from when you have a downturn.”

urn:contentItem:60G9-FV11-F07F-80F6-00000-00Big Tech results move center stage after Congressional bruising2020-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:23:04ZLexisNexisNEWSBig Tech results move center stage after Congressional bruisingSagarika Jaisinghani and Neha Malara

FILE PHOTO: The logos of AmazonAppleFacebook and Google More By Sagarika Jaisinghani and Neha Malara (Reuters) - Four of the United States' big tech firms, accounting for nearly a fifth of the S&P 500's total value, report results on Thursday on the heel... FILE PHOTO: The logos of AmazonAppleFacebook and Google More...

FILE PHOTO: The logos of AmazonAppleFacebook and Google More By Sagarika Jaisinghani and Neha Malara (Reuters) - Four of the United States' big tech firms, accounting for nearly a fifth of the S&P 500's total value, report results on Thursday on the heel...

FILE PHOTO: The logos of AmazonAppleFacebook and Google More By Sagarika Jaisinghani and Neha Malara (Reuters) - Four of the United States' big tech firms, accounting for nearly a fifth of the S&P 500's total value, report results on Thursday on the heels of a bruising Congressional hearing to look into alleged abuse of their global dominance. It will be the first time Apple Inc , Amazon.com Inc , Alphabet Inc and Facebook Inc post financial results on the same day and investors wonder if they can deliver enough to extend a rally that has been central to Wall Street's recovery since March. Deemed "stay-at-home" winners as millions of Americans were ordered indoors to contain the COVID-19 pandemic, shares in the big tech players have scaled record highs at a time when the benchmark S&P 500 <.SPX> is up less than 1% on the year. But with many of Apple's stores still closed and Amazon's e-commerce costs soaring, there are question marks, and some on Wall Street argue that stock prices for all four have been bloated beyond rational valuations. Shares in Microsoft Corp fell 4.4% the day after its report last week, despite better-than-expected cloud revenue and its stock is now nearly flat on the month after hitting an all-time high in early July. "It's simply momentum," Leo Kelly, founder of Verdence Capital Advisors, told the Reuters Global Markets Forum, ahead of the results, due after the closing bell. "When you have stocks looking like they're moving into a bubble, what you don't know is how far it will go. You can't just look at valuation and say 'it's going to fall.' It can go anywhere and the risk is becoming extremely, extremely high." THREATS Alphabet's Google and Facebook took particularly sharp jabs on Wednesday from Democrats and Republicans who say they have crippled smaller rivals in the quest for market share, the latest blows in an increasingly threatening regulatory landscape. Apple's headache is a slowdown in hardware sales as the world slides into recession, with analysts predicting pandemic disruptions will see revenue fall about 3% and the iPhone business by nearly 14%. Similarly, Facebook and Google are contending with a collapse in marketing spending. Refinitiv analysts estimate Facebook could generate its slowest revenue growth - around 3% - since it became a public company. Still, despite the surge in stock prices raising the specter of another tech bubble - Amazon is up 64% this year and the others 13%-29% - analysts remain confident about the longer-term growth prospects for the four companies. "Even the bears will say that these are fantastic companies and they are not going to stop being fantastic," said Nicholas Colas, co-founder of DataTrek Research. "The unifying factor is they have the ability to both grow and control their cost structures through the pandemic. That is always a good place to start from when you have a downturn." (Reporting by Sagarika Jaisinghani and Neha Malara in Bengaluru; additional reporting by Lisa Pauline Mattackal in Bengaluru and Noel Randewich in San Francisco; Editing by Patrick Graham, Bernard Orr)

But with many of Apple’s stores still closed and Amazon’s e-commerce costs soaring, there are question marks, and some on Wall Street argue that stock prices for all four have been bloated beyond rational valuations. You can’t just look at valuation and say ‘it’s going to fall.’ It can go anywhere and the risk is becoming extremely, extremely high.” THREATS Alphabet’s Google and Facebook took particularly sharp jabs on Wednesday from Democrats and Republicans who say they have crippled smaller rivals in the quest for market share, the latest blows in an increasingly threatening regulatory landscape. Similarly, Facebook and Google are contending with a collapse in marketing spending. Refinitiv analysts estimate Facebook could generate its slowest revenue growth – around 3% – since it became a public company. Still, despite the surge in stock prices raising the specter of another tech bubble – Amazon is up 64% this year and the others 13%-29% – analysts remain confident about the longer-term growth prospects for the four companies. “Even the bears will say that these are fantastic companies and they are not going to stop being fantastic,” said Nicholas Colas, co-founder of DataTrek Research. “The unifying factor is they have the ability to both grow and control their cost structures through the pandemic. That is always a good place to start from when you have a downturn.” (Reporting by Sagarika Jaisinghani and Neha Malara in Bengaluru; additional reporting by Lisa Pauline Mattackal in Bengaluru and Noel Randewich in San Francisco; Editing by Patrick Graham, Bernard Orr)

urn:contentItem:60G9-FVB1-JCSC-J15P-00000-00Big Tech results move centre stage after Congressional bruising2020-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:23:04ZLexisNexisNEWSBig Tech results move centre stage after Congressional bruisingSagarika Jaisinghani & Neha Malara

NEW YORK/BENGALURU (July 30): Four of the United States' big tech firms, accounting for nearly a fifth of the S&P 500's total value, report results on Thursday on the heels of a bruising Congressional hearing to look into alleged abuse of their global domi... NEW YORK/BENGALURU (July 30): Four of the...

NEW YORK/BENGALURU (July 30): Four of the United States' big tech firms, accounting for nearly a fifth of the S&P 500's total value, report results on Thursday on the heels of a bruising Congressional hearing to look into alleged abuse of their global domi...

NEW YORK/BENGALURU (July 30): Four of the United States' big tech firms, accounting for nearly a fifth of the S&P 500's total value, report results on Thursday on the heels of a bruising Congressional hearing to look into alleged abuse of their global dominance. It will be the first time Apple Inc, Amazon.com Inc, Alphabet Inc and Facebook Inc post financial results on the same day and investors wonder if they can deliver enough to extend a rally that has been central to Wall Street's recovery since March. Deemed "stay-at-home" winners as millions of Americans were ordered indoors to contain the Covid-19 pandemic, shares in the big tech players have scaled record highs at a time when the benchmark S&P 500 is up less than 1% on the year. But with many of Apple's stores still closed and Amazon's e-commerce costs soaring, there are question marks, and some on Wall Street argue that stock prices for all four have been bloated beyond rational valuations. Shares in Microsoft Corp fell 4.4% the day after its report last week, despite better-than-expected cloud revenue and its stock is now nearly flat on the month after hitting an all-time high in early July. "It's simply momentum," Leo Kelly, founder of Verdence Capital Advisors, told the Reuters Global Markets Forum, ahead of the results, due after the closing bell. "When you have stocks looking like they're moving into a bubble, what you don't know is how far it will go. You can't just look at valuation and say 'it's going to fall.' It can go anywhere and the risk is becoming extremely, extremely high." Threats Alphabet's Google and Facebook took particularly sharp jabs on Wednesday from Democrats and Republicans who say they have crippled smaller rivals in the quest for market share, the latest blows in an increasingly threatening regulatory landscape. Apple's headache is a slowdown in hardware sales as the world slides into recession, with analysts predicting pandemic disruptions will see revenue fall about 3% and the iPhone business by nearly 14%. Similarly, Facebook and Google are contending with a collapse in marketing spending. Refinitiv analysts estimate Facebook could generate its slowest revenue growth — around 3% — since it became a public company. Still, despite the surge in stock prices raising the specter of another tech bubble — Amazon is up 64% this year and the others 13%-29% — analysts remain confident about the longer-term growth prospects for the four companies. "Even the bears will say that these are fantastic companies and they are not going to stop being fantastic," said Nicholas Colas, co-founder of DataTrek Research. "The unifying factor is they have the ability to both grow and control their cost structures through the pandemic. That is always a good place to start from when you have a downturn."

urn:contentItem:60GF-WSD1-DYTY-C23B-00000-00Big Tech results move centre stage after US hearing;Smaller growth expected from Apple and Facebook but investors remain confident of firms' recovery2020-07-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:23:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 27Big Tech results move centre stage after US hearingSmaller growth expected from Apple and Facebook but investors remain confident of firms' recoverySagarika Jaisinghani and Neha Malara

FOUR of the United States' big tech firms, accounting for nearly a fifth of the S&P 500's total value, were due to report results yesterday on the heels of a bruising Congressional hearing to look into alleged abuse of their global dominance. It will be the first time Apple, Amazon, Alphabet and Facebook post financial results on the same day and investors wonder if they can deliver enough to extend a rally that has been central to Wall Street's recovery since March.

Deemed "stay-at-home" winners as millions of Americans were ordered indoors to contain the Covid-19 pandemic, shares in the big tech players have scaled record highs at a time when the benchmark S&P 500 is up less than 1pc on the year.

But with many of Apple's stores still closed and Amazon's e-commerce costs soaring, there are question marks, and some on Wall Street argue that stock prices for all four have been bloated beyond rational valuations.

Shares in Microsoft fell 4.4pc the day after its report last week despite better-than-expected cloud revenue, and its stock is now nearly flat on the month after hitting an all-time high in early July.

"It's simply momentum," Leo Kelly, founder of Verdence Capital Advisors, told the Reuters Global Markets Forum ahead of the results, due after the closing bell.

"When you have stocks looking like they're moving into a bubble, what you don't know is how far it will go. You can't just look at valuation and say 'it's going to fall.' It can go anywhere and the risk is becoming extremely, extremely high."

Alphabet's Google and Facebook took particularly sharp jabs on Wednesday from Democrats and Republicans who say they have crippled smaller rivals in the quest for market share, the latest blows in an increasingly threatening regulatory landscape.

Amazon rose about 1pcyesterday, while Apple, Alphabet and Facebook were close to unchanged.

Apple's headache is a slowdown in hardware sales as the world slides into recession, with analysts predicting pandemic disruptions will reduce revenue about 3pc and depress the iPhone business by nearly 14pc.

Similarly, Facebook and Google are contending with a collapse in marketing spending. Refinitiv analysts estimate Facebook could generate its slowest revenue growth - around 3pc - since it became a public company.

Despite the stock surge raising the spectre of another tech bubble, with Amazon up 64pc this year and the others up between 13pc and 29pc, investors are betting the deep-pocketed companies will emerge from the coronavirus crisis stronger than their smaller competitors.

"Even the bears will say that these are fantastic companies and they are not going to stop being fantastic," said Nicholas Colas, co-founder of DataTrek Research.

Reuters
